TEXT: The applicant , Mr Urmas Velleste , is an NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in NORP .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the applicant , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant was suspected of a number of economic crimes ( fraud and embezzlement ) in respect of which several separate sets of criminal proceedings were initiated on and after DATE . Subsequently , the different criminal proceedings were joined on several occasions ( in DATE , DATE and DATE ) . During the preliminary investigation and trial the applicant was at liberty , except for the period from DATE to DATE , when he was kept in detention because he had failed to appear before the investigator when summoned .
On DATE the bill of indictment was signed by the public prosecutor and the criminal case was sent to ORG for trial .

On DATE the ORG convicted the applicant of some of the charges related to fraud and embezzlement , and acquitted him in respect of the remaining charges . He was sentenced to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , of which he had to serve DATE in prison , the remaining part of the sentence being suspended . ORG rejected the applicant ’s argument about the length of the proceedings . It found that considering the volume and complexity of the case and the fact that the case had been in court since DATE , the length of the proceedings had not been excessive . It added that the “ factor of time , namely the time that had passed from the commission of the acts described in the charges until the delivery of the judgment , and the behaviour of the accused at that time , ... were taken into account by the court when determining the [ applicant ’s ] sentence ... ”

By a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld ORG judgment in substance . In respect of the complaint about the lapse of reasonable time for the criminal proceedings , ORG noted that the case at hand was a complicated and voluminous one , the written evidence comprised CARDINAL volumes , and many witnesses had been heard . It concluded that a reasonable time for the proceedings had not been exceeded . In respect of the applicant ’s sentence , ORG found that the fact that he had committed DATE before did not serve as a ground for not applying “ shock incarceration ” to him .
On DATE ORG decided not to examine the public prosecutor ’s appeal .
On DATE ORG postponed the enforcement of the applicant ’s prison sentence until DATE on health grounds .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s request for release from punishment on health grounds , or alternatively for postponement of the enforcement of his prison sentence . The applicant ’s appeal was dismissed by ORG on DATE . The courts relied on medical information presented by the applicant , according to which he had sustained a serious injury in DATE , had been receiving treatment for back pain since DATE and had been diagnosed with spinal stenosis . Electrotherapy , swimming or other physical exercise had been recommended for him . The courts found that rehabilitation therapy , other than swimming , could be continued in prison and in case of need in - patient treatment was also available .
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ( ORG seadustik ) provides that ORG decides whether to examine an appeal on points of law within DATE of receipt .
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Code stipulates that ORG hears a criminal case within DATE of agreeing to examine the appeal .

By a decision of DATE , in constitutional review proceedings ( case no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) , ORG of ORG rejected a complaint concerning the length of criminal proceedings , noting that the complainant could raise the issue in criminal proceedings before the court hearing the criminal case . It held :

“ CARDINAL . If the court comes to the conclusion that [ the complainant ’s ] right to proceedings within a reasonable time has been violated , the court can , in the light of all the circumstances and on the basis of LAW , terminate criminal proceedings due to inappropriateness , render a judgment of acquittal or take the fact that reasonable time was exceeded into account when passing sentence . ”
The above decision of ORG is more extensively quoted in the case of PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § DATE , CARDINAL DATE ) .

By a judgment of DATE ORG found that the criminal proceedings in the case it was examining had not been conducted within a reasonable time and the defendant ’s sentence was reduced accordingly ( see PERSON , cited above , § CARDINAL ) .

ORG has also found in several judgments that excessive length of proceedings can serve as grounds for the termination of criminal proceedings , the defendant ’s acquittal or taking the length of proceedings into account in the sentence ( judgments of DATE ( case no .
